item.title: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis
item.description: In their art, Tayeba Bagum Lipi and Mahbubur Rahman highlight the experiences of Dhaka's alienated hijra community.
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Time in a Limbo (2014-15) by Mahbubur Rahman – "Hijras don't have job facilities. The are living in society but they are nobody," says Rahman. Hide Caption 2 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Home (2014) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – This two-channel video piece by Lipi shows the artist digging herself a grave on one channel, and a hijra called Anonnya telling the story of her life's struggles on the other. Hijras have limited options to earn money, and many are forced into begging or prostitution. They most commonly earn money by singing at people's weddings or at children's births. Hide Caption 3 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis When the Life Began (2014) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Lipi's installation When the Life Began (2014) shows the artist's childhood photographs juxtaposed against Anonnya's. "I tried to make a connection between her life and mine," says Lipi. Yet despite parallels in their early years their paths diverged with Anonnya being pushed to the edge of Bangladeshi society and Lipi remaining firmly within it. Hide Caption 4 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Lullaby (2014) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – In a sound installation titled Lullaby (2014), Lipi created casts of her face and Anonnya's face and placed them beside a headset. Visitors can listen to both of them singing a lullaby. "There is nothing to distinguish her from Anonnya," says Caitlín Doherty, curator at the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum. "She is very much challenging the viewer about how we make judgments about [transgender] people." Hide Caption 5 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis I Wed Myself (2010) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Lipi's video work I Wed Myself (2010) was inspired by friends unhappy in arranged marriages. In the piece, Lipi transforms into a bride in one video while she simultaneously assumes the guise of a male groom in a second video. "I thought, 'What can you do to make sure you are happy? You marry yourself. The person you know best,'" she says. Hide Caption 6 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Toys are Watching Toys (2002) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – In Toys are Watching Toys (2002), a sculpture of a bride and groom is displayed with a video of a cow being slaughtered projected onto them. An audience of women in burqas is seated in front of them. The piece likens a family sending a bride into an arranged marriage to a religious sacrificial ceremony. Hide Caption 7 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Bizarre and The Beautiful (2011) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Lipi rose to international prominence after exhibiting an installation of bras fashioned from razor blades titled Bizarre and The Beautiful (2011) at the Venice Biennale in 2011. Hide Caption 8 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Love Bed (2012) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Her first major exhibition in the US was a group show at the Guggenheim Museum. The razor blade sculpture Love Bed (2012) was among the most talked-about pieces in the show. Hide Caption 9 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis My Daughter's Cot (2012) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – My Daughter's Cot (2012) alludes to the artist's miscarriage. Hide Caption 10 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis My Mother's Dressing Table (2015) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Lipi's work My Mother's Dressing Table, first shown at the 2015 Venice Biennale, is also on view at the Broad Museum. Hide Caption 11 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Miles After Miles (2015) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – One of Lipi's most recent razor blade works titled Miles After Miles (2015) is on display at Sundaram Tagore Gallery in New York. Hide Caption 12 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis Comfy Bikinis (2013) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Lipi's Comfy Bikinis (2013) installation is made of safety pins. A recent exhibition in Dhaka showing an image of one of her bikinis on a banner was met with opposition. "Some people came and they told the gallerist to remove it. They said it's a Muslim country ... These kind of small things are happening, but it could become a major problem," says Lipi. Hide Caption 13 of 14 14 photos: The secret lives of transgender Bangladeshis The Nighty (2013) by Tayeba Begum Lipi – Exhibited at Art Basel Hong Kong earlier this year, Lipi's work The Nighty (2013) is also made of interlocking safety pins. Safety pins are also significant in the context of Bangladesh. "It's related to the female body. It's a very simple and small tool you always have in your bag to tie clothing. When I was a student and in a crowded place, you would use a safety pin in a crowd if men tried to touch your body," Lipi says. Hide Caption
